title: How William Shatner Changed the World
text:
How William Shatner Changed the World (or How Techies Changed the World with William Shatner in Europe, Asia, and Australia) is a 2005 two-hour television <a href="documentary">documentary</a>, commissioned by <a href="Discovery%20Channel%20Canada">Discovery Channel Canada</a> and co-produced for <a href="History%20%28U.S.%20TV%20channel%29">History Channel</a> in the United States and <a href="Channel%20Five">Channel Five</a> in the United Kingdom. Hosted and narrated by <a href="William%20Shatner">William Shatner</a>, known for his portrayal of <a href="Captain%20James%20T.%20Kirk">Captain James T. Kirk</a>, and based on his 2002 book, "I'm Working on That", the show focuses on technological advancements and people in the real world that were inspired by the "<a href="Star%20Trek">Star Trek</a>" phenomenon.
Summary.
First hour.
The first hour focuses on the original "Star Trek" series and the ideas that <a href="Gene%20Roddenberry">Gene Roddenberry</a> had about the future of space travel.
It begins with the life of Dr. Marc D. Rayman, the chief propulsion engineer at <a href="Jet%20Propulsion%20Laboratory">NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory</a>, and shows how Dr. Rayman became interested in propulsion through "Star Trek". It also discusses how NASA's newest deep space probe's <a href="ion%20propulsion">ion propulsion</a> was inspired by the 1968 "Star Trek" episode "<a href="Spock%27s%20Brain">Spock's Brain</a>". Shatner also states that "those pesky trekkies are everywhere in the space program," hence the name for the first <a href="Space%20Shuttle%20Enterprise">Space Shuttle: "Enterprise"</a>.
The show then examines the life of <a href="Martin%20Cooper%20%28inventor%29">Martin Cooper</a>, the chief engineer at <a href="Motorola">Motorola</a>, who invented the <a href="cell%20phone">cell phone</a>. Cooper states that "Star Trek" was his inspiration for the cell phone, and discusses the similarities between the modern day cell phone and a <a href="communicator%20%28Star%20Trek%29">"Star Trek" communicator</a>. He also discusses how "Star Trek" introduced the concept of computer <a href="speech%20recognition">voice recognition</a> dialing.
Next, <a href="Mae%20C.%20Jemison">Mae C. Jemison</a> describes how "Star Trek" inspired her to become the first African-American in space, and <a href="Seth%20Shostak">Seth Shostak</a>, of <a href="SETI">SETI</a> (Search for Extra Terrestrial Intelligence), tells how it led him to astronomy.
The show also explores how "Star Trek" popularized the notion of the <a href="user-friendly">user-friendly</a> <a href="personal%20computer">personal computer</a>, and how "Trek" fan <a href="Ed%20Roberts%20%28computers%29">Ed Roberts</a>, invented the first home computer, the <a href="Altair%208800">Altair 8800</a>, named after the solar system Altair (Altair 6) in the 1967 "Star Trek" episode "<a href="Amok%20Time">Amok Time</a>". This led to <a href="Bill%20Gates">Bill Gates</a> writing the computer programming language <a href="BASIC">BASIC</a> for the Altair and forming <a href="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>.
Medical technologies are discussed, in particular the inspiration for <a href="medical%20imaging">non-invasive "Star-Trek"-style imaging technology</a>.
<a href="Warp%20drive">Warp drive</a> and <a href="faster-than-light">faster-than-light</a> interstellar travel with theoretical physicist <a href="Miguel%20Alcubierre">Miguel Alcubierre</a>'s theories are mentioned. <a href="Lawrence%20M.%20Krauss">Lawrence M. Krauss</a>, physicist and author of the 1995 non-fiction book "<a href="The%20Physics%20of%20Star%20Trek">The Physics of Star Trek</a>", is also featured.
The show then investigates the research work of <a href="Kevin%20Warwick">Kevin Warwick</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Reading">University of Reading</a> and considers its links with the <a href="Borg%20%28Star%20Trek%29">Borg</a>. Warwick's <a href="cyborg">cyborg</a> implants, linking his own nervous system into the <a href="internet">internet</a>, are featured.
Second hour.
The second hour focuses on further programs in "Star Trek" franchise: ', ', ' and ' and their impact and how they differed from the original series.
Next up is <a href="Steve%20Perlman">Steve Perlman</a>, at the time principal scientist at Apple Computer, who was inspired to invent the <a href="QuickTime">QuickTime</a> media player by watching an episode of "Star Trek: The Next Generation".
Filmed mostly in <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, British Columbia, Canada, the special featured some scenes that took place in locations shown in "Star Trek" TV series.
Awards.
The special was nominated for two <a href="Emmy%20Awards">Emmy Awards</a> in 2006 - Outstanding Nonfiction Special, and Outstanding Writing For Nonfiction Programming.
